A few minutes of research is enough to dig up the scientific paper proving that laser lunar ranging was achieved years before the Apollo missions.

The reason being that the surface of the moon itself reflects enough light for the return signal to be detected.

The supposed mirrors changed nothing. In the myth busters episode dealing with this , the scientist who runs the ranging facility confirms that they only receive back a handful of photons, a number comparable to what was being received years prior without a mirror, and any marginal improvement can be explained by technological advances in laser power, cohesion, optics and sensor efficiency.

By the time the laser pulse reaches the moon, it has spread out to a mile in diameter and the same happens on the way back.

The surface area of regular moon rock is responsible for orders of magnitudes more signal than a tiny mirror would be.

This claim is debunked by science.


Louis D. Smullin & Ggiorgio Fiocco (30 June 1962) "Optical Echoes from the Moon". Nature 194, (1267) doi:10.1038/1941267a0

The New York Times (5 November 1963) "Soviet bounces light beam off moon in a laser test"

Thomas Maloy, Howard Sochurek (December 1966) "The Laser's Bright Magic". National Geographic 130, (874-6)

Mare Tranquillitatis (Latin for Sea of Tranquillity) where Apollo 11 "allegedly" landed is in the middle of the moon. That view/side of the moon always points to Earth. Standing on Earth, we never see the other side of the moon. If the moon was a circle, Apollo 11 landed close to the centre point of that circle. You do not need "a laser reflector" on the moon to measure the distance to the moon. It is just like a laser tape measure you can buy at the local hardware store. You do not put a reflector on the wall 5  metres away. The laser beam bounces back on itself if positioned and targetted on an object perpendicularly at the other end, just like a pool ball bouncing off a cushion, it depends on the angle of contact. If you want the ball to come straight back at you, the ball has to hit the cushion at a right angle. Besides, the laser reflector that was supposedly left on the moon by Buzz and Neil was not even positioned to reflect straight back to Earth.  Because Apollo 11 "allegedly" landed on the middle of the circle moon, Earth would have been positioned directly above the landing site, not off to the side on an angle the way all the NASA photos have the reflector pointed.

The Apollo reflector is 45cm x 45cm = 0.2025m2 and is around 240,000 miles away. Lets say it reflects 100% of the light back to earth. The lunar surface itself reflects 12%. The laser dot after 240,000 miles is around 1km across, or 785398m2.
The reflector than adds (1-12%) * 0.2025 / 785398 = 0.000023 % extra light to the returned laser signal.
The reflector therefore makes no difference at all to anything and is irrelevant. Laser ranging of the moon started in 1962.

I am surprised to find out that nobody has pointed out that plane mirrors do not actually laterally flip images. Physics girl did a nice video showing that the flip is in the Z direction.  When Henry explained the physics he (over) simplified and gave the (traditional) incorrect explanation. If mirrors flipped along the Y axis, when you raised your right hand it would appear to be on the left side of the mirror (not appear like the image raised its left hand).   Mirrors flip in the Z direction so two mirrors means 2 Z-flips and you are back reading the way you started.  The third z-flip is why in 3 axes it will return exactly to sender.  If you flipped each about y-axis this wouldn't happen the same way.  Still, this is a great video.

Gravitational tides (caused gravity being felt more strongly on near parts of a body in some other body’s gravitational field and different rates of “falling”) cause tidal bulges to form on near and far side of both the Earth and the Moon. Each body’s rotation causes its bulges to be slightly to one side of the Moon–Earth axis and as the near bulges are pulled more strongly, slowing down the rotations. The Earth’s near bulge also pulls the Moon faster and faster along its orbit. (Hammer throw!)

Planetary bodies aren't exactly spherical. All moons get slightly flattened and streched out by the gravitational forces that hold them. Because of this imperfection, it takes energy to rotate a moon around its axis. The amount of rotational energy (momentum) that a moon has is not infinite, so eventaully it runs out.
If you want to know more about this, look up "tidal locking" on wikipedia or somewhere else.

I dunno why your comment is flagged. Since I can't find any good reply to your question, I will try to explain. Lightyear  is a measure of distance not time. 1 lightyear is the distance travelled by a photon/light in a year. Therefore, if someone says "the object A is 1 lightsecond from object B" what they really mean is that a light from object a is gonna 1 second to get to object B. Since light travels 300000000 metres in 1 second, the distance between object A & object B is 300000000 metres.

A "light year" is a unit of length, not of time; so it is possible to convert it to an equivalent unit of distance such as km's. It is obtained by multiplying the speed of light (in meters per second) times a year (in seconds):
(299792458 m/s) * (31556925.9747 s) = (9.46052840E15 m)

As you can see the answer is in meters which is easy to convert to kilometers by just multiplying the answer times (km/1000 m) which gives us the distance of a light year translated to kilometers: 9.46052840E12 km.
